Award.AwardTitle: Case Studies and the Flipped Classroom

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The State University of New York at Buffalo's National Center for Case Study Teaching in Science (NCCSTS) is further developing the use of case studies to teach STEM subjects by including the development and use of materials and videos to facilitate a "flipped classroom" design, a teaching method that has shown promise to engage students in a variety of STEM disciplines. In this approach, students learn the subject basics at home by watching short interactive videos, then apply these principles in class to case studies and learn the material in depth. Some video material for this purpose exists from sources such as the Khan Academy, but for the most part new videos are needed that are tailored to the specific goals and content focus of the crucial cases. The project is generating videos for existing cases in key subject areas of general biology that are commonly taught. These subject areas include experimental design, biological molecules, cell structure, DNA structure and function, genetics, evolution, animal and plant anatomy and physiology, health, ecology, and conservation. These topics make up the core of the general undergraduate biology curriculum in this country and are represented by case studies in our peer-reviewed case collection at the NCCSTS. The use of the videos with (or without) the case studies is allowing a diversity of educational and scientific communities to promote active learning, content mastery, and problem solving by students at various academic levels.

This project is being funded jointly by the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Directorate of Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to support Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the Case Studies and Flipped Classroom project (NSF #1323355) was to develop case study materials and videos to facilitate a "flipped classroom" design in the teaching of undergraduate general biology.  Grant participants wrote original case studies, and through grant workshops produced videos to complement them on topics in the general biology curriculum in evolution, ecology, genetics, cell and molecular biology, biodiversity and conservation, animal structure, plant structure, chemistry of life, the scientific method, pseudoscience, and health.

Three three-day summer workshops were held between 2014 and 2016 at which 61 faculty were trained.  At the workshop, participants learned about video production techniques, tools, and software, and were guided through the stages of planning and producing a video with opportunities for gaining hands-on experience with various video production methods. They received information on copyright, story-boarding, editing, and assessment.  The workshop was refined over the three years of the project based on faculty participant feedback.  Lessons learned and best practices are documented in an article produced by the project team titled “Guidelines for Producing Videos to Accompany Flipped Cases” (Journal of College Science Teaching 46:5, 40-48, 2017).

All participants took a pre- and post-workshop survey designed to measure growth as a result of the workshop, and they completed an overall workshop evaluation. Additionally, participants took a one-year follow-up survey to assess the fidelity with which they implemented grant requirements and their intentions for using and developing flipped video case studies in the future. The results of these assessments are included in the external evaluator’s final report.

Project faculty were expected to develop an original case study, teaching notes, answer key, video(s), and pre-/post-test assessment questions.  Of the 61 faculty who were trained through the workshop, 46 completed the work, for a 75% completion rate.

In terms of curricular materials, the grant produced 46 cases; 47 videos: 52 authors; 43 different institutions. (During this time, additional cases were published by the National Center for Case Study Teaching in Science that contribute to the undergraduate STEM curriculum for a sum total of 221 cases; 278 authors; 140 different institutions) A list of cases, authors, and institutions are presented in the final report.  All cases and videos underwent external, double-blind peer review and revision.  The cases are publicly available on the website of the National Center for Case Study Teaching in Science (http://sciencecases.lib.buffalo.edu/cs/collection/) and the videos are publicly available on the National Center’s YouTube channel (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC_u3gZwsmMvQm-iBQ9cCSIQ). 

YouTube usage statistics show a high volume of use for the videos.  The top five in terms of usage include videos on 1) cytoskeleton structure and function (viewed 93,458 times at the time of this report), 2) enzyme function and inhibition (viewed 18,308 times), 3) mitosis (viewed 15,838 times), 4) photosynthesis (viewed 10,331 times), and 5) evolutionary ecology (viewed 8,901 times).  A random sampling of the cases produced under this grant shows that they have been similarly been well received.  En Garde! Animal Structures and What They Mean, which explores how animal structure and function are correlated and the role of natural selection, has been downloaded 17,318 times since it was published on March 3, 2016.  A Different Kind of Stress, on protein folding and trafficking, has been downloaded 11,426 times since it was published on January 22, 2016.  Sweet Beets: Making Sugar Out of Thin Air, about photosynthesis, has been downloaded 27,466 times since it was published on September 28, 2015.  Little Girl Lost: A Case Study on Defective Cellular Organelles, on the structure and function of cellular organelles, has been downloaded 41,772 times since it was published on July 8, 2015.

We learned that the production of videos for flipped cases is a time consuming endeavor that many biology faculty are not well positioned to undertake. Faculty we trained whose home institutions provided additional and ongoing support for video production were more likely to succeed in that task and to produce a higher quality product.  Our assessment data indicate that the workshops were successful in providing participants access to expert advice and mentoring in video planning and production. Participants reported developing a sense of agency around video case development as a direct result of attending the workshops. Many said they would not only continue to develop video cases, but also encourage and mentor their peers in doing so, thus ensuring the sustainability of the grant’s objectives in the future.

 

The use of case studies is established as a major pedagogical method in the instruction of college and K-12 students ever since we helped pioneer the method in STEM education 25 years ago. Our effort during the grant has added a new dimension to case use by marrying the flipped classroom approach to the use of case studies across the major subject areas of the biology curriculum.
